The Sitka Times.
Vol I.     Sitka A. T.? Saturday September 19th two small parallel lines below the th 1868.              No two small parallel lines below the O 1. 
The weekly Times will be published and furnished to Subscribers in Sitka every Saturday at 25 cents a Copy.
Barney O.Hagan? Editor and 
Proprietor No. 57 Market Street
Sitka Al. Terr.
Advertisments.
G. Y. Montagues
House.
Saloon, Restaurant and Bakery, all of which is conducted as a No. 1 Establishment, No. 177h? Lincoln Street Sitka A. T.
Kinkad & Louton
Wholesale and Retail dealers in Dry goods and groceries, Hardware, Wines, Liquors etc. etc. etc. Store in front of Central Park. 
Sitka A.T.
Frank Mahoney
Auctioneer
11:[?] Market Street Sitka A. T.
Advertisments.
Storer and Burgman.
Dry goods and groceries, Hardware and a choice lot of pure Irish, Scotch and Cutter Whiskeys and Wines, etc. etc. etc which they are prepared to sell at such prices as will suit the buyers.
Store No. 29. Lincoln Street
Sitka A. T.
Sam's Saloon.
is still conducted in its usual happy manner. A pleasant smile and good Liquors and Segars is Sams Motto.
S. Melitich Proprietor. 
No. 75 Lincoln Street. Sitka A. T.
City Market.
Isac Bergman the butcher in Sitka was never known to keep an empty market. He has always, when he can find it, lots of fresh meat on hand. 
Market      No. 38 Market Street
Sitka Al. Terr.

Introductions
Today we present the Sitka Times to the citizens of Sitka and the world at large. It is the first attempt ever made to publish a paper in this vast land of Alaska The Times will be devoted to local and general news. We shall when we deem it practicable discuss all questions of public interest, touching the affairs about Alaska. In politics and religion the Times will be neutral. The Pacific Rail Road we are in favor of, and would like it to hear the screams of its whisle echo from the peaks of Alaska, and the musical strain of humanity shouting a Chorus of: " Let the iron horse speed along with its precious burden of emigration. 
We are strongly in favor of a Civil Government and directly opposed to military rulecrossed out d?. Give Alaska a Civil Government, you may soon expect to hear of rich minerals having been fully developed by our latent industry but not before. 
Having no devil in our office the Times should be virtuous. 
As our local items will be [?first?] we shall spare no pains in giving a well defined description of all fights, according in language of flowers the matrimonial pursuits of mankind, with the respectfull details of those whose souls have fled to the Spirit land. 
Editorial 
The appearance of the Times being written instead of printed will perhaps cause many a laugh. In olden times a laugh would be out of place, as written pamphlets and the town criers was the only means alone employed, for conveying news, as no Serving Parties at that time had been established by the ?Fair?. 
To invest in the purchase of a press would incur great expense and until we see better inducements there is now offered, a press can be dispended with, although the copying of so small a sheet as this is, required much labor and some means. Our object in producing such a paper is not with the view of making a fortune, but chiefly, if possible to gratify the Citizens of our Town and for this we shall do our best.

Local.
Seizure. The Steamer Alseander owned by the Messrs, Hutchinson & Co., was seized by the Acting Collectoer Mr. G. Forsyth on the 10th inst. The owners however having given the necessary bonds, she was allowed to proceed upon her voyage to Kodiac, The particulars we forbear to dwell upon, for want of space. 
Salute. In compliance with an order recieived at Head Quarters a Salute of thirteen guns at sunrise was fired, and one gun each half hour during the day; at Sunset.  /13th inst./ thirty seven guns were fired in honor of the death of the Ex President James Buchanan. The Saluting was ably conducted by Battery ?H.D.U.S.? Arty, under the Command of Brt. Lt. Col. Wm. N. Dennison. 
Room Warming. Mr. Hutchinson having moved into his new rooms last Tuesday gave the customary Room Warming, to wich was introduced friends & Champagnes in liberal quantities. 
Capt Ge; H. Dimpfel will act as Ast. Quartermaster here, until Col. Weeks shall return from Kodiac, to where he had already started, to attend a Court Marshall there. 
Sickness. It is sad to witness the number of funerals, that take place here. It is principally confined among the russians. As many as four persons have been consigned to the Grave Yard on a single day.
Departure.  The Steamer [?Mer?] from Victoria sailed on the 15th inst. intending to call at the[?Stick..?] and Fort Simpson on her way down.  The Nor Wester also cleared on this date for Chil bat under the command of Bendell with goods from the well known firm of Storer & Co. intending to trade with the Indians at that place.
The Steamer Alexander having reloaded and again prepaired for sea broke her moorings, taking the Schooner "John Bright" in Tow, the latter bound for San Francisco.
Passengers.  List of Passengers bound for Codiac pr. Alexander, consist of Genl Davis, Genl [?Tidwell?] Col. Weeks, Major Wood, Capt. McGilvery & Capt. McGuire

It is expected that they will return in about two months. A speedy and pleasant voyage is our sincere wish. 
Improvements, Hopes of Sitka are not of the best, but still a hope is left.  The new brewery of Messrs. Levy of 6 is nearly finished. The inside matter is expected up soon, due from San- Frandis Co by the Bark Delaware. When it is completed our citizens will have two Lager beer establishments to buck against. 
Chairs wanted. A prominent establishment in this City wants this special commodity. I like a square meal but can not get it, unless I am seated properly. Who has got any Chairs for sale. Cushions prefered. 
-Gorgeous- 
Aurora burealis in its mysterious grandeur was on the night of the (15?)th inst. beheld by many. Its brilliant and symetrical arches spanned the heavens from S.W. to N.E. illuminating the spacious firmament with a hold of its glory. 
Advertisements of Business Cards
I.M. Manasse will always keep on hand the best brands of Tobacco, also Toys of every variety, playing cards, photographic albums, and Fancy Perfumery. Cheap. Lincoln Street Sitka. 
Hansons Saloon. If you want a choice beverage, go to Hansons, Lincoln Street in rear of Sam's Mill. 
D. Shirpers.  Groceries and provisions, can Fruits and cheap goods of all Kinds. Lincoln Street Sitka. Give me a call. 
L. Chaplans Saloon has the following brands; butter Whiskey, French Martel, Old Tom and all luscious Cock Tails. 
M. Rudolph, Keeps constantly on hand a large assortment of Gents, Boys and Ladies under-Standings, in fact an endles boot variety; all orders promptly filled.
W.H.Wood Attorney & Councellor at Law
Lumber! Lumber! Always on hand at the A.R.Co. Saw Mill at the usual Market Rates.

Dear General Davis
I am much gratified by your very kind & pleasant note which I shall keep & value. Perhaps you may be interested in [?] a small photograph of my husband, taken when he was 48 or so years of age. I enclose it with many thanks for your kind sentiments & good wishes & with the sincere hope of meeting you again in old England, at my own home. believe me Yrs very sincerely
Jane Franklin
Sitka
May 24, 1870

3
Presented by Lady Jane Franklin while on a visit to this country May 1870

Lady Franklin
Miss Sophia Cracroft
Upper Gore Lodge. Kensington Gore.
Personal Record of Marietta A. Davis

Memoranda

Herbert D Ihles (?)
Court Community

83 Market St
Citrate of Lythia tea spoon full in wine Glass of water 2 or three times a day Browning (?) & Sloan

Entrada- Entrance
Salida- Exit
Madame Degollado

Louisville Ky. Feb 20th 1878
We arrived here this morning at 11 oclock. Hoping to go aboard the steamer at once - but much to our disappointment he was not in, but expected every minute- So we went to a convenient Hotel over looking the River and were rewarded in about two hours by the appearance of Steamer Robert Mitchell, bound for New Orleans- We found our room had been served for us so went aboard at once. It is quite a large boat, but already the rooms are filled, one large party being from Pittsburg & another from

Louisville Ky. Feb 20th 1878
We arrived here this morning at 11 oclock. Hoping to go aboard the Steamer at once - but much to our disappointment she was not in, but expected every minute- So we went to  a convenient Hotel over looking the River and were rearded in about two hours by the appearance of Steamer Robert Mitchell, bound for New Orleans- We found our room had been reserved for us so went aboard at once. It is quite a large boat, but already the rooms are filled, one large party being from Pittsburg & another from

Ohio, none of them being known to us. It rained hard all the Afternoon, & we did not get off until near sun-down. When the Capt. concluded to go through the Canal. but spent all night getting through as one large boat & several coal barges were ahead of us. 
21st Passed some [crossed out: pleasant] pretty looking towns today particularly Carrelton & Rockport but as it rained hard all day we did not have a good opportunity for sight seeing - dancing to night till 11 oclock music furnished by negro musicians,

the same who furnish music during meals. 
22nd, The Capt. says this will be an eight day trip or over & I suspect a very tedious one. Found ourself at Evansville when we awoke this morning. It is raining hard as usual. Remained all day at Evansville.Taking in so much freight that I wondered where they would be able to stow it - I went "below" to see how it would be disposed of - found plenty of room, also furniture, corn & cattle on every side. saw one poor little calf which had evidently just come into this world. It looked as if it might perish

with cold- did not go up town it raining too hard- made the acquinatance of Mrs Currie of Newport, also of an old gentleman name unknown (Johnson?).    Dancing in Saloon as usual in which we did not join- took a Lemonade & went to bed at 11 oclock.
23rd Spent about half the day at Shawneetown talking in freight, the most of which was composed of coops of chickens. They were so crowded together that many of the chickens died & were thrown over board,  The conditions of these poor crowded chickens kept me from going on deck as much as I otherwise would.

as it made me feel so badly to look at them. Shawneetown is one of the oldest or perhaps the oldest town in the States. It has a kind of breastwork of Earth the thrown up in front to guard it against the high water, as the town itself is on quite low ground. Passed several towns but none of interest & spent most of the day playing cards & checkers in  ladies cabin.  Reached Paducah this evening after dark - It is only a short distance from the mouth of Tennessee River, bought papers here, read them

played cards, & looked at the dancing until eleven oclock & then went to bed & did not wake up as I expected to when we reached Cairo which is situated at the mouth of Ohio River. found ourselves on the Mississippi this morning. 
24th Sunday - a very long day which was spent partly in singing "Moody & Sankey" hymns & partly sleeping passed Island No. 10 or where it said to be as it has almost disappeared & in a few years no trace of it will be left

New Madrid is not much of a place, the Bank [?caves?] in so at this point that the town itself is in danger of being swallowed up by the River - our Dentist & Wife left the boat here -
Passed Fort Pillow in the night & found ourselves in Memphis when we awoke.
The Boat is now heavily ladened, the Captain refuses any more freight - We had an addition of a number of dogs - & cattle today the latter making a great commotion among the

negroes,[?hitting?] them &  knocking them over -  a number of the cattle escaped and we had to go off and leave them.  The dogs, roosters and turkey Keep up quite a commotion below.  Became acquainted with a number of people & spent the evening listening to Mr. Dailey's  Irish stories -  he is the life of the Boat - being the first in the dances & in every other amusement which is gotten up. He leaves at Memphis for Hot Springs. 
23-12 Took my first drink of Blue Lick water today. It is excedingly disagreeable but had the desired

effect. This has been a most beautiful day & have been out on deck the most of the time, begin to see indications of being in a southern climate, the holly bush and cane I [?] making their appearance. The land is very low and looks as if it might be half the year under water. Stopped at Helena this afternoon. There are some beautiful residences there, but it is made up principally of tumbled down old buildings. Saw two men feed the 225 dozen chickens which are on deck, it was funny sight. Mr. Johnson (an

old gentleman from Ohio) and I went among the sick ones & gave them water to drink as there was none provided for them. We had an entertainment in the evening consisting of Music, Recitations & "Telephonic" music, said to be from Louisville KY. All sing good for an impromptu affair. Wound up the Evening with a game of cards with Mr. and Mrs. Powers of Pittsburg & a young Lady with an unpronouncable name, Mrs. P__ is going South for her health she is quite delicate. I suspect has the

consumption. My next door neighbor is a very pleasant & pretty young lady from Natchez. She is very anxious to pass by her home and go on to New Orleans to see "Mardi Gras" of course. 
26-15 This is a beautiful day, have been out on deck the most of the time. Passed some beautiful plantations, saw one field of cotton which had not been picked, the grass is now becoming quite green & the peach trees are in many places in full bloom. Passed Gerard McMillain's plantation in Louisiana. Stopped a placed called

Refuge, which before the war was the Large Estate of Judge Griffin - he is now dead. His fine house has disappeared in in its place is a miserable looking town.  Here we took in a great quantity of oil cake used for feeding cattle.  There were immense quantities of cotton seed here for shipment. This seed is used for a variety of purposes besides planting - the oil obtained from it being used for making lard even. A gentleman told me he had eaten biscuits

made with it which were very white & nice & tasted well. it is also used for making candles, soap & is exported from this country & then manufactured into table oil, sent to this country again & there sold as genuine olive oil.
At this place the negro "boy" George came aboard and entertained us with a "break down",  & songs by which he "cleared" about two dollars -
There was a black bear on shore here which became quite lively at the sight

of so many people & danced about on his hind legs.
Took in passengers at a little town called Lake Providence, which has the River on one side & lake and the other. Here during the war Grant had a cannal dug from the River to the Lake thus [?] overflowing the Lake & causing much destruction of property between this point & Red River
Had an entertainment by "King Rex" this evening , which consisted of songs - imitations of all kinds of animals & buzz saws &c

played cards until 10 1/2 oclock at night when we reached Vicksburg. Went on shore here, but the streets were so dark & rough & the hills so high that we did not venture very far.  I was disappointed as I had hoped to see the place by day light. Took a Lemonade & went to bed at 12 oclock.    
27th  Beautiful day, spent it looking at the scenery, saw a great many fine plantations and a great many deserted negro quarters, went ashore at Natchez. Climbed a

very steep hill to get there, but was rewarded, it is a beautiful place, found flowers of all kind in full bloom,  The magnolia and camellia grow abundant here, the latter is now in full bloom. Succeded in getting a bouquet made out of the latter together with hyacinth , geranium. buttercups &cc -  distributed among the young ladies to put in their hair.  Went through the market but it was almost bare. "Natchez under the Hill" is made up of shanties the town proper being upon

the hill. Saw a great many "Aunties", with their bright colored dresses & turbans. A beautiful girl living here got aboard of the boat, a Miss Marsh. A perfect southerner & just as attractive as she can be. Passed Fort Adams, but could not see the town, but saw the site of the old Spanish fort, it has disappeared with time. Near here in a grove was the grave of Mrs. Myra Gaines Father, who once owned a large

plantation here. Reached the mouth of Red River just at sunset & saw a little steamer passing up is just going out of sight as we came in. There is a little stopping place there & three beautiful plantations owned by a wealthy widow, who a few years ago made herself notorious by having her face enamelled while in Paris, she being assured it would remain so for years. In twelve months it was ready for a second application, which so enraged her that she took her case to

Court & sued the 'Artist' for damages. History does not state whether she recovered any or not.  Passed Bayou Sara at night & could see nothing of it except the Landing, unclear there is not much beyond this to see, but our "boy John" was born here & brought up here & for that reason I wanted to see it so that I could tell him how it looked now.  Played checkers with Charlie Currie & watched the dancers till I retired at eleven o'clock.

28th This is a lovely day & the scenery is as the Pilot Mr. Anderson said, the finest on the route.  The sugar plantations on both sides of the River. Each one with its sugar mill & negro cabins looked like a continuation of villages - We saw a great many handsome houses thickly surrounded by evergreens, among which the live oak was conspicuous, it is one of the most beautiful trees I ever saw.  The holly & Magnolia were abundant, and almost every house had an orange

grove near it. scratched out line I saw about half a dozen trees loaded down with their ripe fruit - Passed a fine College for Boys - Had an early dinner so that we got through before making Carrolton, which is a suburb of New Orleans. Arrived there a little after one oclock & found quite a number of steamers & ships - arrived safely at New Orleans at 2 oclock, and spent an hour or scratched word so seeing the unloading of the vessel. The poor chickens having

another rough time of it. One turkey escaped and went "aloft" in the rigging of the boat.  - I hope they may never get him. J-- found after a search one room at the St. James. We bade good bye to our friends on board, got together our baggage and after a safe trip of 8 and a half days down the Mississippi are at last at New Orleans on this the 28th of Feb 1878

line with two dashes

New Orleans double underlined - Arrived here on the last day of Feb, and succeeded after a long search in finding rooms at the St. James on Magazine St.  We were just at the top of the house having three awful long stair ways to climb, but as the whole city was crowded, it was "Hobson's" choice with us. As soon as we got settled we went out for a long walk, looked in the shop windows, visited a cotton press - a place where the bales are pressed down to about half their original size, so as to give more room in shipping -  it was a very interesting process to me, Walked as far as we could & then took

the street cars back to the hotel, had a very nice dinner, & sat out on the long gallery to cool off & get up [?courage?] to go up stairs, which we did, got a nice rest & then set out again at 8 oclock to hunt up the procession, the "Knights of Momus". we succeeded in getting a good position & were of course delighted with the "Scenes from the Realm of fancy" -- which it is impossible to describe - Went home and took a bath notwithstanding I could get [?some?] hot water  - Slept soundly until the morning of this

1st March.  Had a splendid breakfast, saw the General off to see Genl' Auger & then set out alone to see the  sights.  found a great many French people keeping shop.  They were universally polite, visited some fine china stores.  Returned home to dinner & found the General had succeeded in getting a room on the first floor of Mrs McConnell's on      [?Campt?] St. to which we removed after a dinner of "Gumbo & Oyster Soup," shrimps & crabs, which we enjoyed very much -  Our room is full of easy-chairs & sofas, but is too dark to be very pleasant.

we take all our meals in our room.  Took a long ride on Street-cars.  Saw some beautiful residences & a profusion of all kind of flowers in full bloom & any number of orange trees loaded with fruit.  We pay 50 cts per day for oranges here but they are fresh.  Stopped in the Cemetery on our way back. The bodies are almost all put above ground in [?] vaults or tombs.  Read Beulah all the Evening as the General was out all Evening having been invited to meet Beauregard, Hood and other Confederate heroes.  Went to bed at 12 tired out -

2nd Another beautiful day - Went out to buy a pair of slippers, had quite a search for a pair which suited me, which I found at a French store called the "Red Star" - also bought a flower for my neck. - Had several calls to day - I started out for another walk in Evening which wound up in a visit to the Robert Mitchell saw quite a number of our old friends & went to the Academy of Music to see the Minstrels - It was one of the worst performances I ever saw, I was glad to be in my in my room & bed at 11 oclock

3rd Sunday Did not get up in time to go to the French Market as I had intended, had a late breakfast & at one oclock we took the Canal St. cars & started to visit the cemetery, which we reached after a ride of about five miles over a not very attractive country, We visited the new cemetery which is now on the same ground as the race course use to be. It will be a beautiful spot in a few years, but there are very few tombs & none are very handsome

In "Greenwood" we saw the monument erected to Lee,  Jackson, Polk and A S Johnson by the Ladies of this State. It has a bust of each of these officers [-and- crossed out-] on the side & on the top is a statue of a soldier with Army coat & cape & resting on his gun.   Bought Japan plums & dates. The first I had ever seen of the former, I do not like them much. When I returned home, I found [-had- crossed out] that [?] had found my red roses which had so mysteriously gone from my room. One of the servants

girls had appropriated it. Saying she had found it on the street!
4th Monday Had a nice breakfast of fish &cc   At 12 oclock the Firemens procession began to pass, it was a very fine display of Engines & men.   The Engines were very handsome the most of them being nickled plated, & looked too handsome for use.  New Orleans is well equipped with Engines but, badly off for water or means of getting at it.  I am told they have never had any very large fires there.  We went over to Major Glenn's quarters and

had a second fine view of the procession - it took a little over an hour to pass there. Took a walk down Street to see the crowd & get a glass of mead found it very nice. Had a call from Mr [?Susamore?] an old school master of J--whom he had not met for over twenty five years. also a call from Major Eckles & Genl' Bussey - Retired very tired at 10 oclock. 
[Seems a half page has been torn off and the second half of the following page is revealed]
with us afterward as our boarding house - We had cards of Invitation  "Mystic Krewe" reeption [unclear] to Rex reception but felt too tired to go   The procession this evening, Exceded any

"Rex" & [?Sesirte?] arrived this afternoon in R.E. Lee & paused here with his baggage on his way to the St. Charles. He was escorted by United States troops & band - 
5th - Mardi Gras at last! Children out bright & early all in mask. Everyone excitement & on the lookout.
The Worthingtons came over from ?Strainer? & we had one unclear 
[torn page on top of this one]
supplied with unclear but, badly off for water or means of getting unclear it - I am told they had never had any very large unclear there - We went over to Major Glenn's quarters and

to ourselves when the procession passed scratch out. It was very grand & consisted of scenes from Mythology.  The whole headed by Agamemnon & his body Guard.. We had two fine views of it one from Major Glenn's on St Charles street- J- took the Miss Worthingtons  Mr ?Grismore? & my self over to the Richelieu saloon scratched out Restaurant where we had a nice lunch--Mr Worthington dining with us afterward at our boarding house.  We had cards of Invitation to "Mystic Krewe" reception, also to Rex Reception, but felt too tired to go. The procession this Evening Exceeded any

we had yet seen was grand beyond description--All Mythological - We took a walk down street about 1 o clock at night to see the crowd & were rewarded by being pushed & josttled about in Every direction--The illumination of the  Pick Nick Class rooms & other buildings were very fine--Took a glass of "Mead" at McCloskey's and came home tired of sight seeing.
6th underlined The most important Event to-day is Jef's first trial of glasses or spectacles, He says they assist him very much in reading.  Took Lunch over at the

Richeleau Restaurant again, but I only took a biegne glacé which was very fine, it being made of cream altogether. Took a long walk down to the French part of the town, the streets are very narrow, & most of the buildings are very old.  Heard nothing but the French Language spoken while there.  Had a call from Col.di Trobriand of 13th Infantry. We are to go out to the Barracks tomorrow if pleasant.
7th [underlined] Over slept ourselves 9 o clock when we woke, hurried through breakfast & took the cars for Jackson Barracks-which is about five miles

from Canal Street--We were over an hour getting there & arrived in a shower, but found the Commanding Officer waiting with an umbrella for us at the [crossout] Cars. He was very Kind showing us all over the Post. & were introduced to a number of Officers--Saw the house in which J-  lived over twenty five years ago. We were much pleased with our visit, returned by the French Market & levee. Saw a ship loaded with cotton on fire, a great many bales being destroyed.  Took Lunch at a French Restaurant on

Canal St. and at 3 oclock took the "dummy"  for Lake Pontchartrain, had a delightful ride of seven miles, met our new friend Miss Carleton & spent the afternoon walking and watching the vessels. The breeze was delightful & we did not get back till almost dark, to the City--Had a Call from Col. Perly &  Major Glenn
8th [underlined] Wrote letters, recd' Mr [?Gensamiene's] receipt for making "Gumbo soup", by mail.  Took rides all over the City in cars, went to see Mrs Auger & from there to the theatre, but could not get seats &

returned home "tired to death" I went to bed early.
9th Our last day in New Orleans! J - took passage for us on the Steamer City of Mexico to Vera Cruz which sails tomorrow - Very sick all day but succeeded in getting our  trunks packed in time to go on the steamer to night. Went in a fearful rain storm with thunders and lightnings found no passengers aboard & but few hands - finally succeeded in getting to bed but slept little owing to want of air - I fear I am going to be very

sea sick. 
10th Sunday Got a cup of coffee & feel better.  A delightful day. It is just one hundred miles to the Mouth from New Orleans - Find quite a number passengers on deck mostly French & Spanish - We passed the Eleanor Shannon which had run in to an Iron clad vessel at the foot of Canal St - It had floated quite a distance down stream, & the Banks are strewn with cotton. We could not hear whether any lives were lost, although the Boat was a complete wreck. Passed the Monument of Jackson (Andrew) it is just about

a mile from the Barracks. & on the spot where, Jackson threw up his famous breast works, of cotton in his fight against the English. 8 Jan, 1813 - The Battle was fought after the Treaty of peace as neither Jackson or English knew of the Treaty owing to the tardiness of mails. We are passing lovely plantations - mostly sugar- some of rice - The sugar cane is beginning to make its appearance above the ground - vegetation is very far advanced here. The rice plantations are all surrounded by ditches, for irrigation -

The negro quarters are all good. The most of them being white-washed which make them looking very pretty in under the live oak trees. The "English Bend" forms almost a Peninsula of this land. There is a very fine plantation here, The English had their  Encampment here during their fight with us.
Passed an very large plantation completely submerged the Levee having broken away - most of the houses being deserted.  Here I saw the first rice growing. It is a beautiful bright green. The land is quite low on both banks & were it

not for the Levees the land would be completely submerged--Back from the River are the Cypress swamps--the trees are covered with the long grey hanging moss--
Passed about 12 oclock the "Magnolia Plantation" belonging to Mr. Bradins Johnson, it being the largest orange grove on the coast. It Extends 2 1/2 miles along the shore--Mr Johnson also owns two or three more farms between here & New Orleans--sugar plantations--At one oclock today we passed Fort Jackson & Fort St. Philip just opposite

each other, It was here that Farragut & Butler ran the gauntlet--That is Farragut lashing himself to the mast of the Flag ship, The Hartford, and passed between the fires of the two Rebel forts & reached New Orleans--23 miles from mouth of the River--Passed a large English Steamer, name unknown.   Entered the South pass & passed the Light house & Eads Jetties about 2 1/2 this afternoon--About twelve miles from the entrance to the Gulf. -- Shore lined on both sides with swamp cane, & reeds--which are filled with

Alligators Unclear it is too cool yet for them to be basking in the sun as they do in warmer weather. Passing more Jetties, these are formed of wooden posts driven down & a net work of cane laid over & between them & kept in place by stones.  They then serve to obstruct the smaller channels & thus drive the water through deeper ones, for the passage of larger vessels. Passed a number of oyster men & fisher men cabins, put up on piles so as to keep them from floating off--Have seen the first Island in the Gulf about 10 acres. & half dozen trees.

Have just passed a larger ship from Breman, waiting for a Steam tug to take it up to N. O.
Arrived at Port Eads at 3-35 this afternoon--it is at the mouth of the South Pass & consists of the a light house  & about a dozen houses with coal barges & steam tugs lying around loose--There are quite a number of vessels here, Port Eads seems to  lie on both sides of the pass--Can see the white caps on the water not far off, they are very suggestive of sea sickness.  Well we shall see!  We are approaching the breakers & can see distinctly where the Gulf & River meet.

11th--Very sick as expected
12th--Was very sea sick 
13th--Arrived at Tampico Mex about eight this morning. I was glad to get out on deck although feeling quite unsteady. There is no harbor at this place, but the Steamer "lays by" about three miles from shore , & is communicated with by little Tugs & liters (lighters) of which there were quite a number.--The town of Tampico is five miles inland up the River, but on clear days the church spires can be seen--
A great many Mexicans came aboard here.

14th Arrived at Tuxpan. This also has no harbor but takes in passengers & freight the same as at Tampico, The town is also inland. The Light house also in full view--here more "natives" came aboard bound for Vera Cruz--all getting sick as soon as entering the Steamer as (I am told) is the custom of Mexicans - We have had for the last two days a very smooth sea & all the sick are able to be up & are rejoiced that we will be on terra firma in the morning--
15th Arrived at Vera Cruz just at 7 oclock this morning--No harbor

but anchor in the Roadstead & are reached in small boats--
There are a great many vessels lying here, one belonging to our Navy. The City is surrounded by a heavy stone wall. & has huge gate way by which to enter.
We are stopping at the Hotel "Mexican" which faces the Emmense gate way at the landing. And opposite where  Genl' Scott's Headquarters were, It is a very old thick stone walled house with little balconys in front of each room. No windows except in the doors--No carpets except oil cloths in the little narrow rooms, and the floors of the halls.

are iron slats or grates giving a draft from garret to cellar.  The bed rooms all have cots or single beds, I see no others, and room & halls are lighted by candles set under large glass cases to prevent their being blown out by the wind--Our dining room is on the Restaurant style, food served by men, & cooked up in real Spanish style. The only familiar dishes to see today were Unclear soup, baked custard in a cup--Have had visits from some of our Steamer friends today, Dr. Way starts for City of Mexico to night, poor old man  I hope he will get through safely--

We took a long walk tonight & passed through a very beautiful but small park which so far seems to me to be the only breathing place in the City as the streets are quite narrow, & houses built close up to each other having more the appearance of dungeons as there were so many barred or close shutters to the windows.  All the streets are paved with cobble stones, with a drain running through the middle, the buildings are of stone or brick flat roofed & most of them covered with tiles--The great walls are some parts of them at least made of bricks & mortar. The stones used in building the City were

taken from reefs of rocks in the harbor.  One gate-way bore the date 1727, There are a great many guns still up on the walls. We passed Barracks & saw quite a number of Soldiers in their white uniforms but not very tidy looking & just now we could hear them beating off tattoo which reminds me of home--Want to go in some of the old churches, also visit the Castle of St. Juan de Loa. (de Ulua) It faces the town being built on a reef in the Harbor & when built was considered the largest? fort in the world it is now occupied as a Prison with Military guards.  Mosquitoes troubled us all night--

16th--Up early this morning owing to chatter of Mexicans rolling in bales of cotton. Found the waves rolling very high so that small boats could not go to or from the shore, no Ships will be able to leave today there being a "Norther" but not a very hard one comparatively.  After breakfast we took a walk through the principal streets, All but working people stay within doors through the heat of the day. In the Plaza saw two very large cocoanut trees loaded with fruit, also a Palmetto Fig, and Oleander Irises in bloom--saw no curiousities so bought a few shells--Returning home, under a sheltered side walk

We sat down & ordered Chocolate, which was very firm, also a peculiar kind of bread to eat with it. 
Visited the Library which is a very thick stone-walled building, very old having been at one time a Church. We here saw the tomb of the Wife of Cortez & read the inscription on the slab--she died 18th Dec. 1663--In the Library was quite a collection Aztec curiosities among them Iron stirrups each weighing several pounds.
Dr Trowbridge, the American consul here took us up to his house, where we met his Wife & daughters & had an opportunity to see the interior of one of the houses--The stair way

occupies the center of the house - the rooms being on all sides of it, the stairs are of stone or brick, and floors are all either large bricks or marble--Each family occupies a floor or flat. There are no yards or gardens--Visited the market this evening saw a number of vegetables, peas cabbage, tomatoes, lettuce, raddishes, beets & fruits, a great many of which are new to us & which we have tasted - Bought a fine fresh pine apple for 18 3/4 cts. Went this Evening out side the walls & were surprised by seeing quite a number more modern houses, some wooden, also a lovely grove of cocoa nut trees loaded with fruit, a fine broad walk led through the center of grove

and a fountain was playing - Saw three companies of soldiers pass with Officers, each company seemed to have several laundresses with it--
17th J- went out before breakfast to get a cup of chocolate, we then went to the Market, which was quite a sight & crowded with people--where the people could not find booths to spread out their wares, they had spread it out on the ground all around the square, bought a bouquet of pink roses mixed with a sweet smelling herb for 12 1/2 cts--Saw green corn, egg plant, sweet potatoes, chickens, turkeys and a variety of other things which I had never seen before. Amont them the calabash

a gourd shape vegetable, also the tamarind before it is preserved. The cauliflower and lettuce grow very large here, & the lettuce is very tender, Went to Mass at the Cathedral at 12 oclock, The services are similar to those in any other Catholic Church except  when services were over some of the people remained & went from one group of wax figures (representing our Savior, Blessed Virgin & Saints) to another praying & kissing the floor,  The better class of people were seated but the Indians were kneeling, the Elderly Spanish Ladies were in black with light black shawls thrown over their heads, but the young ladies had lace scarfs over theirs, all men bare headed of

course, J bought me a very pretty pair of silver buttons from an Egyptian woman she had brought them from Hindostan--Had a long visit from Madame Degollado this afternoon, she told me she had been Maid of Honor to Carlotta  (Empress Carlota) and also that she had been robbed eight times in this country once having thirty thousand dollars worth of jewels & clothing taken -- J- went up to see the consul this evening so I finished my letters to Unclear & Ida.
Hope I will have a good nights rest--
There are no wagons is this place, nothing but a few dump carts & drays, the latter are twice the width.

of our drays & are drawn by always two & mostly three mules put abreast--Milk, water, charcoal & a all Kinds of marketing are carried about the town on little donkeys, the load some time covering the little fellow so that you can only see his head & tail--I see a few mustangs & a few horses used in carriages.
18th Spent the morning watching the Passengers coming in from the French Steamer there are quite a number of them, All as well as our selves have had to have their trunks searched.  Madame Depollado & Husband have just gone aboard (12-o'clock) of the English Steamer, which

takes them to New Orleans--She expects to be very seasick, but the water today is as calm as a River & there is no difficulty in loading and unloading today. This has been a lonely day, as I have been alone almost all the time, There has been quite a number of arrivals from the City to night, the most of them on their way to the French Exposition. There are some quite pretty young Ladies among them, J began to wear his Liver pad yesterday. I hope it may do him some good--
Took my dinner alone today, which consisted principally of beans & lettuce.

Dr insert Dr Samuel J Trowbridge called & went with us to visit his Daughter, who is married to Mr Petersen a German merchant here--
They live in the style peculiar to the country, but very nice. They have lovely rooms, no carpets but brick floor & rugs. They told me their house was over 250 years old & had been at one time a school or Convent. Next door to them was a house with pillars which Mr. Petersen said indicated that it belonged to a noble man, as none but persons of rank were allowed to have pillars. Spent a very pleasant evening & went to bed at 10 o'clock.
19th Very warm morning, Eat three boiled eggs for breakfast because there

was nothing else I could eat - Almost every dish which is cooked here, has onion or tomatoe mixed with it, particularly the meats--Breakfast is always ended by fried bananas & fruit--The residents here have coffee in the morning any time from  5 to 9 and then a breakfast from 9 to 12 & from 3 to 6 dinner with a cup of coffee chocolatte or tea in the evening just before going to bed--
Mrs Petersen called at one oclock & took me with her to visit the Club Rooms of the Merchants' Club - They were very handsomely furnished  The floors being of inlaid wood in the dancing hall, with elegant chandeliers, lace curtains. There was a very fine

supper room, with handsome silver glass ware, and all the needfuls for giving balls, also reading rooms, wine rooms &c   Spent the after noon & evening at the American Consul, had a nice dinner it being a mixture of American and Spanish dishes. The dinner was served by Indian waiters--The young ladies gave us some nice music, I had the first good cup of coffee there that I have had since I left home.  Took a long walk this Evening but saw nothing new--Had an orangeade & went to bed early.

20th--Was awake nearly all night, on account of the wind. A terrible "norther" sprung up which will probably prevent ships going out for several days--How I pity the Ladies who are on board, as we can see the Steamers rocking like cradles. Mrs Petersen sent me some books to day--& although they are "back numbers" I have contrived to pass the day pleasantly with their aid--We took another walk to the Palm Grove, sat down & enjoyed the breezes, & J got a nice cup of coffee & I of chocolate when returning home--Norther still blowing  I went to bed listening to the beating of the waves against the great walls.

21st--Another bright day and a pleasant breeze, the "norther" still keeps the Steamers from leaving.  One small row boat has just come ashore, it looks as if it might upset every minute--the harbor is full of sharks watching & waiting for their dinner. We leave to night for City of Mexico.
22nd--Spent last Evening with the Consul's family & at 11 1/2 o clock took the train for Mexico--Through the Kindness of the Consul, we were enabled to secure a Compartment to ourselves, which gave us plenty of room for sleeping &  moving around--This road was built by the English & is owned now by them, Mexico gave them the right

Inserted top margin after word "way" in the continuing sentence--And to insure safety from 50 to 100 soldiers are sent in each train as an escort
continued from previous page under insert  of way & contributed twelve million dollars, While the English put in eighteen million.

   The cars are English, the first class being divided into compartments, & the other two classes being like our common day car--The scenery was very fine & just at day dawn we found ourselves in the midst of tall mountain peaks Crossout with some with snow capped tops, with mountain streams & little water falls running down their sides--Passed through many Mexican farms--where their chief crop seemed to be tobacco, stunted corn, & banana groves. There was a very great profusion of wild flowers along the road And at  Orazava? (Orizaba), where we

stopped for coffee, I saw geraniums, vinca, Larkspur, Roses & a variety of other flowers. 
We passed through several old towns, whose principal features seemed to be the old churches, & tumbled down walls, And the most interesting feature of the whole ride was our slow winding in & out of mountains & valleys untill we reached the top, & from there we had a fine view of the villages below, cultivated fields, winding mountain streams, & the natives with their little donkeys (looking like little insects) creeping along the steep sides of the mountains. Took breakfast at Esperanza where our principal dish was a very fine omelette, Mount Orizaba towering

above all others with its snow capped peak, is in fine view here, & we traveled several hours without losing sight of it. The last half of the trip becomes monotonous, on account the the miles & miles of cactus & century plants through which we pass with nothing else except an occasional village, old & tumbled down with its inevitable Church & ruined walls. This is the "Land of pulque" Crossout (a drink made from the tapping or pressing the juice from the heart of the Century plant, & allowing it to ferment.} Men women & children press round you at every stopping place to get you to buy this milky looking stuff, the Spanish & Mexican people in the

cars seemed to be very fond of it & we saw a great many barrels ready for shipment also skin sacks.  Showing it to be a great drink here.  The plant from which it is obtained is cultivated by the acre & is planted in rows as are our cabbages.  As we approached the City we passed old Aztec ruins & bought a few little pieces of pottery picked up around there.  Was [?] to reached the City just at dark, dusty tired out & headaching.  At the Depot had to have even our small  baggage examined.  The officers were very particular about one little box of jewelry I had, asking us a great many questions.  Had some trouble getting

to the Hotel as about half dozen men claimed pay for moving our baggage when only two had been employed - but finally settled the matter & were glad to get in Room 55 at the "Iturbide" which for the present is our resting place.
23rd  Beautiful day, cant get breakfast till after10 and so had to get coffee instead.  Had a splendid nights rest, headache all gone & after having a breakfast at eleven o'clock started out for a walk,  The sun was very hot, so we did not go past a few blocks, sitting down to rest in a little Park.  The fountains were all dry owing to a scarcity

of water in the City, but there was quite a profusion of flowers. I there saw blue phlox 10 feet in height & forming a very large bush. We have felt nothing of the oppression of which so many complain, caused by our great altitude  (7000 feet) This Hotel was at one time the home of Emperor Crossed out words  Iturbide & is quite extensive, there is a little court just under my window filled with trees, shrubs, flowers, a grotto & a little stream of water & all kinds of birds have their home here among them a flock of quail. There are three summer houses, where if we choose, we can take our meals-"Aimee"  &

Torn Paper/letters missing
Established a Church here. In our walk of a few blocks to night we saw a great many beggars, some of them Unclear in Vera Cruz. Unclear sentence due to torn paper
her troupe seem to have taken possession of it, & with their three or four pet dogs make it quite lively.
24th  Sunday, Had breakfast at 10, which consisted of soup, then boiled eggs, then fish & artichokes, then beef steak & potatoes, coffee and fruit.  Dr Skilton the Consul General called while we were at breakfast.  Took a walk this afternoon to the Alameda a very large park where we saw  quantities of flowers in

of water in the City, but there was quite a profusion of flowers, I there saw blue phlox 10 feet in height & forming a very large bush.We have felt Unclear page torn
bloom, this must be a beautiful place when well wattered, but now every thing is dusty-& the fountains all dried up.  Took another walk with Genl' Reneau this Evening, he showed us the oldest Church -San Francisco - in the City. It was quite a large one and with garden attached, The Methodist have bought the Church, & now are holding services there, under their Missionary Dr Butler--Mr Hutchinson, a Presbyterian, also has

established a Church here, In our walk of a few blocks to night we saw crossout--quite a great many beggars, some of them crippled, in Vera Cruz. I never saw so many badly deformed & crippled people.
25th--Had coffee & took a very long walk. Stopped & saw the Indian women making "Tortellios" a species of pan cake. They are made out of corn, worked & passed through different processes of grinding  boiling & mixing with water till it becomes a pulp when it is made out in flat thin cakes & baked quickly--these cakes are peddled round the church crossout the ?same? as bread, they have a very pleasant taste.--

Went to the Larger Cathedral it was crowded, although it is an immense building. The Altar occupies the center of the building & the people kneel or stand around it, I saw no old pictures here as Vera Cruz.  I bought me a lovely boquet of violet--there was every variety, which we see at home. We went to call on the Consul Generals family, which resulted in a most delightful day. I spent the afternoon, & at 2 oclok Mrs Skelton, Gen Reneau? & I in his coach, with the Consul & Jef in the buggy took a drive, first going to the Citadel, which was

the last place taken by our troops in the war of '40--Gen. ?Reneau? showed us where our Troops march along by the Acqueduct & showed the works taking them by [[Unclear] We then drove out the "Empress drive" so called from being planned by Carlotta, this is a beautiful wide drive, with a large statue of Columbus in bronze and other smaller pieces of statuary, on each side, it extended to  Chapultepec. [crossed out sentence] Chapultepec is the old Spanish fort which was used as a military school, it was stormed & taken by our troops during the Mexican War.

It stands on a high bluff, commanding a fine view of the country, & was a look out for Montezuma--he having his tent pitched under the emmense red wood & cypress trees in the woods below,  These trees are planted in Avenues, & are lovely with their festoons of gray moss, These must be very old as they were very large when Cortez made his conquest here--near here is Montezuma's bath, enclosed by a stone wall--We had a view of the ?battle? field of Molina del Rey, also the ruins of the old Church were the Priest stood in the door with his Crucifix as Troops passed--praying them to not touch his Church.

[Words along the left margin are obscured by a torn page over this one]
Genl Reneau told me he [?] there that met a man offered to go near the Church & so it was left for Time to [?] the Destroyer, & he has left nothing but a mass of ruins.  We had a delightful drive through the Empress [?] home, just at dusk.  [?] many fine [?] the wealthy citizens & what is more wonderful [?] companies of [?] soldiers distributed through the drive to protect those driving from robbers!  Went to bed tired 6 1K Took coffee at a caffe & then took a walk, going to Museum.  But only went through           [?part?] of the grounds.  Saw a great collection of

[a torn page obscures the writing on the right margin of this page]
It stands on a high bluff commanding a fine view of the country & was a look out for Montezuma - he having his tent pitched under the emmense red wood & cypress trees in the wood below.  these trees are planted in Avenues & are lovely with their festoons grey moss.  These must be very old as they were very large when Cortez made his conquest here - near here is Montezuma's bath enclosed by a stone wall.  We had a view of the [?battle field of?] Molina del Rey also the ruins of the old Church where the Priest stood in the door with his Crucifix as our Troops passed - praying them to not touch his Church.

Genl' Reneau (told me he was there) that not a man offered to go near the  Church & so it was left for Time to be the Destroyer, & he has left nothing but a mass of ruins - We had a delightful drive through the Empress [?drive?] home, just at dusk.  [?Meet?] many fine [?turnouts?] of the wealthy citizens & what is more wonderful saw companies of mounted soldiers distributed through the drive to protect those driving from Robbers!  Went to bed tired
25 1K  Took coffee at a caffé & then took a walk, going to Museum.  But only went through part of the grounds -
Saw a great collection of

Aztec curiosities Among them their "God of War" which consisted of a big [?] lided stone, covered with hyeroglyphics &c.   [?] used many kind of human faces, hands & feet.  There was also an enormous stone on which human sacrifices were made.  This was also covered with figures of all kinds, human forms in reclining positions, frogs & coiling snakes completed the collection.  We called the American Minister's wife Mrs Foster & went from there to a 1 oclock breakfast at the Consuls, which we enjoyed very much being a combination of

American & Mexican dishes.  After which the Consul family, Genl' Reneau & our selves took the Street cars & went to see a very handsome French Garden Tivola where we had several games of ten pins, and a lovely walk, the Calla Lily grows here very rank it is regarded here as one of their commonest flowers we saw hedges & borders of it yesterday.  The [?] aqueducts which supply the water for the city are wonderful pieces of masonry & were built many years ago by the Spaniards - Both carry  the water from a spring which comes out of the hill upon which Fort [?Chipultipec?] is built

that are about 3 miles in length.  We took a walk through the American Cemetery it is a lovely little spot & kept in good order by the Consul.  There are quite a number of graves here but the principal one to me was the Monument to the memory of American Soldiers who fell in the five battles fought in the valleys around here.  There are about 700 hundred buried here.  The monument is a simple granite shaft.  I gathered a few flowers here- Rode home through Caratolls private drive.  Enjoyed it, but thought of robbers all the time.

FIC Vaugier  2A SnFrancisco No 9 Mexico
No 21 d, nb  $0.63
Equindad et la justicia
Marietta A Davis
Bought in the City of Mexico 27th March 1898
Personal Record

Ticareso   Gerajes

Mrs. J A Skilton
Jacksonville - Tompkins Co. New York

27th March Wednesday

    The ladies ride horseback here a great deal, going early in the morning before the sun is too hot, and returning for breakfast at 10 or 11 oclock, from eleven and four oclock it is very warm here, but the nights are always cool, so that we sleep comfortably under [?] or thin blankets.  This is the dry season, & the dust is very disagreeable. In June the rainy season begins lasting several weeks.  It then rains every day at four oclock

in the Afternoon.
We visited several picture stores today but saw nothing of any particular interest.  We bought a small picture on Ivory.  I am anxious to get some of the old pictures painted on Copper.  Dr. Skelton has quite a number of them, all of them being sacred subjects and evidently having been in Churches.  Mr. Skelton has the bones of the arm of a human being evidently a Padre or Priest - When

the dome of the old Church San Francisco was taken down, there were found quite a number of skeletons in the Dome.  Having been burried there years ago, as a mark of distinction.  Dr. Skelton's house was formerly enclosed in the walls with this old Church & was a Convent.  it is over 300 years old.  Mr. Lan found several new varieties of fruit here.  One called the Mamey is the shape of a small musk mellon, with a rind which peels off (like a bananna) has a very large brown

seed and tastes some what like a paw-paw.  the alligator pear grows here, also musk mellon (we have seen no good ones)  Also a plant (which is like the passion flower)  the end of this being hard as a fruit.  We had  a long conversation & an interesting one with the French Engineer who came out on the Steamer with  us.  He has lived in this Country for a number of yrs & is now interested with an American

Association in  building the Rail Road from the Atlantic to Pacific through the Peninsula of Mexico - a distance of 169 miles, thus shortening the distance 1500 miles.  They are only waiting for this Government to give them the right of way.  He gave us some very interesting information in regard to the Aztecs,  He says that Large sacrificial stone which we saw in the Museum was found near the old Cathedral, & that this

Cathedral which is 300 years old is built on the ruins of an old Aztec Temple.  The two Pyramids which we passed in coming to the City, he thinks were built before the time of Aztecs.
28th.  Took our coffee at a new Café it was an improvement on the others.  Took a walk saw nothing new except hearing quite a number of the bells of the old Cathedral sing out suddenly as we stood just in front of it.  Its towers are full

of bells - all of which are rung on state occasions-  Saw an old Priest a Monk came to the Church door with a silver plate which he he held out for contributions - I have found out the name of those tall straight trees which grow in the court just in front of my window.  It is the Camphor tree of Australia & is a very rapid groath [sic] these being but three or four years old &  now tower above the three or four story house around here -

We went this afternoon with Mr Avery a young gentleman of Michigan, to the Museum & had a very interesting visit. We first visited the Natural History department--The collection here was very large, including the Minerals of the Country, Fish, Birds Reptiles, Plants, Insects  &c.   Saw an Emmense [sic] Aerolite or Meteorite which was found near here, Also several mummies, We were also taken to see private collections of Aztec curiosities, their gods

cooking Crossout-implements utensils, musical instruments, war implements, & cc   Here we saw Montezuma's banner, which he surrendered to Cortez, it was taken to Spain & after being kept there 350 years, was returned to Mexico a few years ago.  It is made of hides, something the shape of a shield, and is  ornamented with other different colored small  pieces of skins, & feathers. Here we also saw Cortez banner a battle flag

it was also made of skin on parchments--with a large figure of the Madonna & a Spanish inscription stating that it belonged to Cortez. There is a very fine collection of old relics here--Returned home, took dinner & spent the evening at Dr. Skiltons, playing card and looking at curiousities of which they have quite a number. The feather pictures here are quite handsome.

29th This has been a busy day. We went out and bought a can of potted ham & then stopped in a Café, where with some of this with bread & a cup of Crossout chocolate coffee, we made quite a respectable breakfast. At 12 o'clock we took a carriage & went round to Minister Foster's for Breakfast. Had a splendid breakfast, & visit until four, when we went by appointment to visit President Dias [sic], Mr. Richardson, Secretary of Legation, & Mr Foster

accompanied us to the Palace--We were received in the Reception Room by the President & Mr. Romaiso. (one of the Officials) who acted as Interpreter--Dias (sic) has been President since Crossout Dec Nov. 76'. He is a native Mexican, rather dark, & has a very pleasing face he speaks a little English, he does not like to use it. We had a very pleasant conversation, he invited us to come again & go all through the Palace, as he said there were a great many

things to interest us.  He told J  he would have a review of the Troops for him, but this J declined but told him he would be glad to meet the Officers.  The room in which we were received was a very handsome large one, with dark wood pannels, a very handsome carpet & crimson furnishing.  The walls were hung with crimson satin, with the coat of arms of Maximillian & motto, "Equidad et ca justicia".  There was also a very fine oil portrait of the first

Emperor Iturbide [Interbide crossed out] - a full length portrait taken in the country - some handsome lamps & chandelier & another picture or this completed the furniture of this room & we saw no other, I hope to make another visit.  
We left the Palace for a drive, which we enjoyed very much, going first to the Cemetery to see the Tomb of Juarez.  They are building quite a handsome stone building in front over his remains.  We from there visited

the old Church built by Cortez, which is over 350 years old, & is not now used, close by this stands the large old tree under which Cortez stood & cried the night his Troops were defeated & driven out the City by Montezuma.  The tree is called the "noches triste" or "sad night" tree.  This is a very interesting historical place.
We returned home just as the sun was setting through the principal Avenue - the "Empress

drive," and saw the usual array of fine carriages, filled with elegantly dressed Ladies, Mexican beaux on horse back in their full dress, which is beautiful to see.  And mounted soldiers to preserve order & at the same time to protect the people from robbery which has been known to be committed even in this public place.  At the Alameda, a park four or five blocks from here & on one of the principal streets, it

is said to be dangerous to pass through after dark, owing to the Robbers who secrete themselves there.  We bought today from an old Spaniard three old pictures on copper, all  sacred subjects, and have evidently ornamented some church.
30th  Took an early breakfast at our new boarding place a Restaurant kept by an old Englishman, from there went  to Dr. Skilton's & met Mrs. Skilton by appointment & were driven to Tricabaya, a beautiful

little suburban town about 5 [crossed out: three] miles from the City but our chief object was to visit the residence and grounds of Mr. William Barron an Englishman or rather Irishman, who after accumulating considerable wealth, fitted up this place.  He does not live here much of the time, owing to [?] but it is a great object of curiosity to visitors on account of lovely grounds fine pictures &c.  The grounds are beautifully

laid out, with all kinds of trees, flowers, grottos, a [?], summer houses, a lake with swan floating about, and handsome bridges all well cared for.  The house is chiefly remarkable for the number of rooms & the quantities of fine pictures which are in every room.  Most of these  pictures as usual are sacred subjects.  The Chapel contains the finest picture of the whole collection, & is one of the finest pictures

I ever saw - The subject is "The Crucifiction" [sic]-  The Chapel has a small altar, pews, & all the appointments of a Catholic Chapel.  The walls & ceiling are covered with crimson silk damask.  We enjoyed several hours here looking at the curiosities.  In one room was a bouquet of Artificial flowers among them a very large rose colored rose, which on close inspection proved to be a tiney clock, a small butterfly sitting in the center of

the rose furnishing the hands, its feelers doing that duty.  There were some very handsome [?] cabinets & tables in the home, also vases.  The view from the front gallery is very fine.  We went out this afternoon to find Opals, but were not successful as most of them were defective particularly the large stone.  The opal stone is found in quantities in some parts of Mexico & when cut & polished is quite valuable.

Saw a funeral today.  The mules attached to the hearse were at a full gallop.  That I am told is the usual way & some or a very few carriages go with it.  The Ladies (I am told) never attend funerals.  There seems to be three grades of society here & among the district ladies of the first class comprises those who wear the lace mantle on their heads or have taken to the American style of

wearing bonnets, (these are few) the second those who wear shawls over their heads, & the third class comprises those who wear the rebosa or long woolen or cotton scarf with fringed ends over their heads.  These last are chiefly the native Mexican
31st Sunday.  I went to bed last night with the head ache & was sick all night & do not feel much better.  Shall keep out of the sun today as I was

convinced that too much exercise yesterday is what is affecting me now, [?]
The manner of courtship among these people is very different from any thing we do at home.  When a young man "falls in love" with a girl, he goes and takes his station on the side walk opposite her house & then he stands by the hour or else promides [sic] back and forth looking up to

the balcony in front of her window, if she favors his suit she will remain out in the balcony, flirting with her handKerchief &cc - if not she goes in slamming the window behind her, in which case his case is at an end.  if she favors him, this solitary promenede will some times be kept up for weeks & months, varried [sic] by his sometimes laying

his hand on his heart & sighing, he will then manage to meet her on her drives and at little parties where she is never alone & if they should happen to become engaged he is allowed to visit her in the presence of others.  Lookers on have all the benefit of this courtship, & I am told as they pass the love sick young man they laugh

& make remarks to him, to all of which he is perfectly oblivious or apparently so.
We bought some quite pretty feather pictures this morning.  They are made by the Mexicans.  They generally ask double prices for every thing they bring to sell, & will only come down to the proper price when they find they cannot dispose of their wares otherwise.  It takes a shrewd person to

deal with them.  
We spent another pleasant evening with Dr. & Mrs. Skilton.  They are very interesting people, having traveled all over this Country.  She has kept a journal, which proposes to print some time.
1st April.  Monday
Mrs Foster & I started out early this morning to visit the "Pawn" shops, a place where all strangers go, both to look & buy.  There are quantities of every thing here & when

unredeemed are very reasonable.   We saw most magnificent diamonds here, pearls opals and all kinds of Jewelry besides house hold furniture & clothing of all kinds.   We saw a magnificent diamond pin, with the coat of Arms & Monogram of Maximillian - a present from him to a Friend, who becoming hard pressed for money had pawned it & had not been able to redeem it

the price was $400.  The Largest shop of this kind in the City is in Cortez old Palace.  Theres an cutting through the walls to make a new front & I had an opportunity to see the thickness of walls - between three & four feet - J- & I went out this afternoon & bought an old fashioned pair of earrings of pearls & gold.
Took a walk tonight up to the Plazza to hear the Band, which plays there every

evening  just in front of the Palace.  The Park was full of people promenading & listening to the music which was quite fair.  The band stand was a very handsome little iron & brass structure brought from Paris & presented to the Plazza by Carlotta.  There must be some thing musical going on as the Palace is illuminated & there was a Salute of 21 guns at sunset this evening.

2nd April.  After breakfast took a drive with Mrs Skilton visiting several filagree silver establishments where we saw any amount of handsome things.  Were impressed to see that they made the filigree work with [crossed out: gold] silver wire in blocks of charcoal!  Went home with Mrs. Skilton & had a nice dinner.  Have found out what the Salute [?meant?]  It is always done both on the opening &

closing of Congress (this opened yesterday)  Today is a [?proud?] holiday in honor of [?Dias?] victory over the French five years ago at Puebla.  The Military are out in full force also the chief men of the City - J - was invited, but did not feel well enough to go.  Genl' Reneau & Mrs. Skilton spent the evening with us.  She is a most interesting woman has spent ten years in Mexico & travelled

in every direction - Harry Skilton brought in a quantity of green moss which he gathered from the "Halls of Montezuma"
3rd April  We took a long walk this [crossed out: evening] morning, visiting the Bazaars again bought one picture on canvas, very old - "Mater Dolorosa" - Had a grand surprise today J- came home after a long absence, bringing me a most beautiful & valuable

present, It being the very pin which Mrs. Foster & had admired so much.  the present of Maximillian to his Friend.  It had been presented to Maximillian by the Emperor of Austria, who in turn presented it to his Friend.  the pin is made up of silver, gold & diamonds.  The whole bearing the crown, Coat of Arms, & motto of Maximillian.  also coat of Arms of Mexico.  With monogram

of Maximillian.  I am very much pleased with it,  Took a delightful drive with Mrs. Skilton this evening - going out to Chapultepec.  We drove out through the grounds & getting out of the Carriage, reached the top by way of large stone steps, laid on the rugged side of the hill, The same spot over which 30 years ago Our Troops went to [?] and took the old Fort.  We entered the huge iron gate

and were within the walls.  There were many Changes going on [?] there.  Building, tearing down & improving - Troops will be quartered here, & it will be a summer home for the President.  The view from here is grand - The City of Mexico lying before us in the valley - surrounded by chains of mountains above which "The Woman in White" & Popocatepilte tower with their snow capped summits.

In the distance is the Sacraficial [sic] Mound where, for years at Stated periods Human sacrifices were offered (by the Aztec's) to their God of War - until Cortez put a stop to it.  Green field, Avenues of fine old trees, old churches and little villages make up a most beautiful landskape [sic] - just before us his [sic] the scene of one of our battles Molino del Rey -  The old mill is still

standing which our troops stormed, & were repullsed [sic] with heavy losses - Chapultepec was much improved by Maximillian.  The walls repaired & strengthened, he also built the drive going from the old Castle to the foot of the hill & planted trees on bot side thus making it a most beautiful drive.  
Took another drive on the Paseo, which of course we enjoyed.

4th  We very early this morning succeeded in getting our breakfast & off to Guadaloupe on the [?] cars  by eight oclock which is quite a feat with us, who have over slept ourselves so much since here.  The ride was pleasant & the road beautiful the cars passing through an Avenue of shade trees, all the way from the out skirts of the City to the train which is a distance of about three miles.  &

all the distance at intervals of perhaps three hundred yards are shrines dedicated to the Virgin of Guadeloupe - & in years past, the people who wanted to do some partial as pennance, have gone on hands & knees from the City to the old Church on the Hill (Stopping at every shrine to pray)   The Old Church owing it origin to this - so was the story - an old Padre living at this village below the Hill

had under his care an Indian boy & one day during the boys rambles alone the Virgin appeared to him telling him that he should tell the Padre to have a chapel errected [sic] to her.  The boy told the Priest who only laughed at him & did not believe his story.  A few days after the boy was again wandering about when the Virgin again made her appearance, telling him

to go to the top of the hill & there he should gather his blanket full of roses, which he showed then to the Priest.  The boy went & was surprised to find roses, where always before there had been nothing but bare stones and cactus.  He filled his "rebosa" or blaket [sic] and on emptying it, the Priest was surprised to see the impress or figure of the Virgin on the blanket - (where it is

to this day - The old Padre went to work built this little Chapel on the Hill & dedicated it to the "Virgin of Guadalupe".  This was built ten or fifteen years after the Conquest by Cortez.  All the pictures or Rosaries we saw of this Virgin represent her wrapped in the blanket.  The identical blanket is now in the larger Cathedral at the foot of the Hill & is preserved with Care.
I could not learn the

history of the Cathedral at the foot of the Hill except that it is very ancient.  We were fortunate in going there as mass for the repose of Souls of Pius IX was being celebrated thus giving us an opportunity to get a look in both the Cathedral & the Capel [sic]  of Guadaloupe.  The former is much the style of all the old Churches we have seen here, pictures & wax figures predominating.  There are quantities of

old bones heaped together under the Altar here being remains of illustrious characters & Saints [?crossed out: Sang?]  the Chapel is much smaller & and is reached by a narrow road way walled up on both sides leaving a space between for the [?graded?][?sodd?] and stone steps, which are many.  I saw here the first wax figure of a black saint although I am told there are quite a number of them.

throughout the Country.  The floor was thick here with slabs to the memory &c showing it was or had been used for a grave yard.  Just below this Chapel stands a large stone sail The history of which is that a Mexican returning from Abroad encountered a fearful storm on the Ocean & in his fright he called on his patron Saint "Virgin of Guadaloupe" to save him & made a

vow that if saved he would erect a monument, which he did, & a very lasting one it will probably be judging from its size - Just below the Hill stands a very small Chapel its whole interior being taken up with a natural spring of bubbly mineral water, the ingredients being soda & iron - This Spring has been consecrated -  is holy water,  On a certain day every year the Indians meet here

from miles around to get a drink of this water & those who cannot get to the Fountain do not hesitate to drink it as it flows down the street through the filth.  There is another small church here but it has no history.  The town itself without the churches is of no interest except that there are here some famous hot baths.  A great resort for
